item.title: Game Trailer Showcased By IGN Slammed For Using AI ‚ÄòPlaceholders‚Äô
item.content:encoded:
‚ÄúHell is empty and all the devils are here.‚Äù That quote from Shakespeare‚Äôs The Tempest is how the debut trailer for hack-and-slash adventure game Fallen begins. It was accurate if you count among those devils the scourge of AI slop. The trailer, an IGN exclusive, was flamed on social media for appearing to showcase gen AI work, and the developer of the game later confirmed it.

The Fallen trailer appeared on X on Monday where it immediately made a splash far beyond what you might have expected from its otherwise generic-looking, demon-slaying gameplay. ‚ÄúIntroducing Fallen, a new Xbox 360-era inspired character action game where you play as Astra, a fallen angel who must battle through Hell and its demonic forces. It‚Äôs in development for console and PC,‚Äù read the marketing copy.

But what stood out to people immediately was the now familiar whiff of slick but lifeless gen AI-produced art that was peppered throughout the trailer. ‚ÄúIt looks nauseatingly bad, genAI isn‚Äôt just walking back gaming hardware, it‚Äôs trying to make the games themselves awful too,‚Äù wrote cosplayer Kitty Bit. ‚ÄúThis is the most AI ass AI video game I ever did see lmao,‚Äù wrote Twitch streamer Ms5000watts. ‚ÄúLooks like a weird amalgamation of AI and jank,‚Äù read one of the top YouTube comments. 

They aren't even trying to hide it brahüò≠üò≠AI slop content is off the charts now https://t.co/uWFQdopCy8 pic.twitter.com/b0B9Jnm8aq

‚Äî Oshbard (@Ludvicus) January 19, 2026

Was this another example of people being paranoid about gen AI and jumping the gun with the accusations of slop? Nope! Superboo Studios founder, director, producer, and writer Brooke Burgess admitted as much after the backlash, but claimed the gameplay was real and in-engine UE5.4 work. Burgess blamed ‚Äúcontext‚Äù collapse for the controversy.

‚ÄúWhat ended up being shared as an ‚Äòofficial trailer‚Äô was actually our early dev ‚Äòtone pitch‚Äô, i.e., a work-in-progress UE5 teaser designed for funding discussions,‚Äù he told TheGamer. ‚ÄúThere are [AI-Generated] placeholders in there, specifically some 2D test assets used to explore mood and presentation (for example, how ‚Äòlost souls‚Äô and fallen angels in the game might react when spoken to and judged, along w/ WIP HUD elements). That material was never intended as final content, nor as a statement on how the shipped game would be made.‚Äù

To go back to referencing Shakespeare for a moment, Burgess seems to be suggesting that ‚Äúthe fault, dear Brutus, is not in our ‚Äòtone pitch AI placeholders,‚Äô but in ourselves.‚Äù He makes it sound like IGN posted the wrong trailer, or jumped the gun. In actuality, Burgess has had no qualms about using AI slop to pitch the game to potential investors.

In fact, he recently complained about just how hard it is to raise money for making a game right now. Burgess said every publisher he‚Äôs spoken to is asking how he‚Äôll us AI to streamline development. He‚Äôs open to using it for QA and localization, but claims he‚Äôs not ‚Äúwaving the flag of AI by any stretch.‚Äù but claims he‚Äôs not ‚Äúwaving the flag of AI by any stretch.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to sell my soul and be like, ‚ÄòYeah, I‚Äôll do it by myself, let me prompt this whole game into existence,'‚Äù he recently told GamesIndustry.Biz. ‚ÄúNo, I want to work with really talented people and make something cool. But if integrating it in a way that doesn‚Äôt affect creativity, but helps to save a little bit of money and gets the game out there to people, and gives us a chance to make something cool and memorable, and then make something else after that‚Äìit‚Äôs something I have to factor in.‚Äù

item.title: Fallout Season 2 Finally Brings Back Two Classic Pieces Of The Franchise
item.content:encoded:
Fallout season two‚Äòs latest episode provided one of the coolest reveals in the show‚Äôs run and was also a great moment for fans of ‚ÄúPointing at the TV and going ‚ÄòOh crap!'‚Äù in front of their friends and then getting to explain why they were so excited.

But wait. Before we go any further, we‚Äôre about to completely spoil that cool moment (and only that moment) from season two, episode six of Amazon‚Äôs Fallout show that brings back not one, but two classic elements from the old Fallout games. So if you want to avoid that, this is the part where you turn around and never look back. Everyone else, keep scrolling.

After being super-punched through a window at the end of the last episode and left for dead by Lucy, the Ghoul is saved from his spikey predicament by a large, strange-looking figure. That figure is revealed to be a Super Mutant. Yup, the Fallout show has finally brought these big ol‚Äô bastards into the series, and I‚Äôm happy to see they aren‚Äôt the brutish-looking monsters so frequently depicted in Bethesda‚Äôs Fallout games. Instead, this Super Mutant looks and sounds a lot like the kind seen in the older Fallout CRPGs and New Vegas.

Technically, a dead Super Mutant appeared in season one in an Enclave base, though we only saw its large green hand sticking out from underneath a sheet. But this is the first time we‚Äôve seen a living Super Mutant in the show. That alone would be cool enough, but there‚Äôs more to this moment. The actor behind the Super Mutant makeup is Ron Perlman, a man who has a long history with the Fallout franchise.

SUPER MUTANT have arrived in #Fallout and he wanted o join Ghoul in his kind pic.twitter.com/30PD4PpZ0p

‚Äî sanmeyo (@oyemnassxo) January 21, 2026

The movie and TV actor has acted as a narrator in most of the Fallout games, including the original ones back in the ‚Äô90s. He‚Äôs the guy who famously says, ‚ÄúWar. War never changes,‚Äù at the start of so many Fallout adventures, and who also often provides a recap of your choices and their outcomes at the end. He also appears in Fallout 4 as a TV newscaster you can hear in the background during the game‚Äôs intro.  And now he‚Äôs here for the Fallout TV show, and I‚Äôm very happy about it.

It‚Äôs good to have you back, Perlman. Hopefully, you got paid more than $40 and a sandwich for this role. 

Perlman‚Äôs Super Mutant character, after saving the Ghoul, mentions that the ones to blame for all of this are the Enclave, a mysterious group of fascists that planned to take over the United States before the bombs fell. The group later claimed to be the inheritors of the United States‚Äô power and authority after the world ended. And it seems they are going to play a big role in the final episodes of Fallout season two.
